senses.de: A fact or condition connected to an event or action.
senses.ex: We will discuss your case in more detail once we get to know the circumstances.

Tips.title: Event Connection
Tips.description: Refers to the influencing factors or conditions related to an event, not just any detail.
Tips.example: The judges considered the circumstances leading to the athlete's disqualification.

Tips.title: Context Specific
Tips.description: Used to describe details that impact understanding or outcomes of situations.
Tips.example: Given the circumstances of the case, the verdict was fair.

Tips.title: Variable Influence
Tips.description: Indicates that situations can change depending on various circumstances.
Tips.example: She might join the trip, depending on her work circumstances.

senses.de: The conditions of one's life especially in terms of money.
senses.ex: His family was not well-off; they lived in difficult circumstances.

Tips.title: Financial Context
Tips.description: Highlights one's financial condition or socioeconomic status.
Tips.example: His circumstances improved after he got the new job.

Tips.title: Life Changes
Tips.description: Used when speaking about transitions in life that impact financial stability.
Tips.example: Moving to a new city can greatly affect your financial circumstances.

senses.de: An event or situation that is necessary for something else to happen
senses.ex: The report's release is expected today, barring any unforeseen circumstances.

Tips.title: Conditional Scenario
Tips.description: Describes a scenario with specific requirements for something else to occur.
Tips.example: Only under the circumstance of a unanimous vote will the policy change.

Tips.title: Necessary Conditions
Tips.description: Highlights the required situation for a potential event or action to take place.
Tips.example: Certain circumstances must be met for the contract to be valid.

Condition.wordDefinition:
Circumstance refers to a fact or event that surrounds a situation, while the word condition refers to a state that something or someone is in.

Circumstance is often used to describe external factors that affect a situation, while condition is more likely to be used to describe an internal characteristic.

For example, a circumstance may be the weather conditions, the time of day, or the location of an event.

A condition may refer to someone's health, a machine's functionality, or the characteristics of a specific material.

However, circumstance is often used when discussing events or situations that are outside of our control, while condition is generally used in situations where the subject is something that can be changed or improved.

Circumstance describes external facts or events affecting a situation, while condition refers to the state of something or someone.

Context.wordDefinition:
Context refers to the background or larger situation in which an event occurs. It sets the scene for what's happening at the moment.

For example, if someone is making a joke about a serious topic during a comedy show, the context is the comedic environment.

Context is more controllable and dependent on the people and setting around it.

In summary, circumstances are the specific events that occur, while context is the broader setting in which they occur.

Contingency.wordDefinition:
Contingency refers to a possible future event that may or may not happen.

It describes a situation where you have to plan for different scenarios because you don't know what will happen. For instance, a company might create a contingency plan in case of an economic downturn or a natural disaster.

Circumstance describes a situation that has already happened, while contingency describes a situation that may happen in the future.

Eventuality.wordDefinition:
Circumstance and eventuality are similar in that they both refer to a situation or condition that may arise. The main difference is that circumstance refers to a particular situation that exists at the present moment, while eventuality refers to a potential situation that may or may not occur in the future.

However, if you prepare for the possibility of losing your job and set up an emergency fund, you are anticipating an eventuality that may or may not happen.

Circumstance is more commonly used to describe a current situation, while eventuality is used to talk about potential future situations.

Factor.wordDefinition:
Factor refers to something that contributes to a result or outcome, and could be either positive or negative. For instance, hard work, determination and good health are all factors that can lead to success.

In short, circumstances are usually external events that happen to a person, while factors are more internal characteristics or attributes that individuals possess.

Happen.wordDefinition:
Circumstance refers to the situation or conditions that surround a particular event, whereas happen simply means the occurrence or taking place of an event.

If someone says "I heard a loud bang, something must have happened", they are referring to an event that has taken place.

Circumstance is applicable when referring to the specific details and conditions of an event, while happen is applicable when simply describing the occurrence of an event.

Occurrence.wordDefinition:
Occurrences are specific events that happen during these circumstances. For example, during the meeting, an occurrence might be the discussion of a particular topic or the decision to take a certain course of action.

So, circumstances refer to the general situation and conditions surrounding an event, while occurrences are specific events that happen within those circumstances.

Situation.wordDefinition:
The words circumstance and situation are often used interchangeably to describe a set of conditions or events that affect a person's life or a particular event.

A situation is a set of circumstances or conditions that arise from a particular event, action, or decision.

A situation often involves a specific place, time, or activity and can be influenced by a person's actions.

For example, if a person gets lost in the woods, the situation would be the fact that they are lost and need to find their way back to civilization.

Circumstance describes broader external factors that shape a person's life, while situation refers to a specific event or condition that a person finds themselves in.

State.wordDefinition:
State, on the other hand, refers to a broader condition or status, often reflecting an internal aspect or characteristic.

For example, "she was in a state of anxiety before her exam."

Circumstance refers to a specific external situation, while state refers to a general internal condition.

quotes.Text: Attitude is more important than the past, than education, than money, than circumstances, than what people do or say. It is more important than appearance, giftedness, or skill.
quotes.Title: American Clergyman
quotes.Name: Charles R. Swindoll

quotes.Text: Well, first of all, you read the script a million times. Because what the script gives you are given circumstances. Given circumstances are all the facts of your character.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Viola Davis

quotes.Text: You must take personal responsibility. You cannot change the circumstances, the seasons, or the wind, but you can change yourself. That is something you have charge of.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jim Rohn

quotes.Text: If you're talking to a man who wouldn't fight with you under any circumstances whatsoever, then you're talking to someone for whom you have absolutely no respect.
quotes.Title: Canadian Psychologist
quotes.Name: Jordan Peterson

quotes.Text: It is a fact often observed, that men have written good verses under the inspiration of passion, who cannot write well under other circumstances.
quotes.Title: American Philosopher
quotes.Name: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.Text: The people who get on in this world are the people who get up and look for the circumstances they want and if they can't find them, make them.
quotes.Title: Irish Playwright
quotes.Name: George Bernard Shaw

quotes.Text: Real life is the life that's in you, not your circumstances, like where you live or what job you have or who you're in relationship with.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Joyce Meyer

quotes.Text: If all our happiness is bound up entirely in our personal circumstances it is difficult not to demand of life more than it has to give.
quotes.Title: British Philosopher
quotes.Name: Bertrand Russell

quotes.Text: The ideal man bears the accidents of life with dignity and grace, making the best of circumstances.
quotes.Title: Greek Philosopher
quotes.Name: Aristotle

quotes.Text: Character, not circumstances, makes the man.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Booker T. Washington
